question_text:
Lucia drew a scale drawing of Portal testing facility. In real life, the chamber is 50 metres long. It is 90 millimetres long in the drawing. What scale did Lucia use?
9 millimetres : ___ metres
solution:
Write the ratio of the width of the chamber in the drawing to the width of the actual chamber. Write the ratio in fraction form.
$\frac{90 \text{mm}}{50 \text{m}}$

Simplify the fraction.
$\frac{90 \text{mm} \div 10}{50 \text{m} \div 10} = \frac{9 \text{mm}}{5 \text{m}}$
The scale of the drawing is 9 millimetres : 5 metres.

question_text:
Lucia drew a scale drawing of Sonic's Green Hill Zone. In real life, the loop section is 150 metres wide. It is 180 millimetres wide in the drawing. What scale did Lucia use?
6 millimetres : ___ metres
solution:
Write the ratio of the width of the loop section in the drawing to the width of the actual loop section. Write the ratio in fraction form.
$\frac{180 \text{mm}}{150 \text{m}}$

Simplify the fraction.
$\frac{180 \text{mm} \div 30}{150 \text{m} \div 30} = \frac{6 \text{mm}}{5 \text{m}}$
The scale of the drawing is 6 millimetres : 5 metres.

question_text:
marine biologist Ocean measured a aquarium and made a scale drawing. The scale of the drawing was 2 centimetre : 2 metres. The main tank is 8 centimetres in the drawing. How wide is the actual main tank?
___ metres
solution:
Write the scale of the drawing as a fraction:
$\frac{2\text{cm}}{2\text{m}}$

Write an equivalent fraction with 8 centimetres as the numerator:
$\frac{2 \text{cm} \times 4}{2 \text{m} \times 4} = \frac{8 \text{cm}}{16 \text{m}}$
The actual main tank is 16 metres wide.

question_text:
cyclist Lance, a professional cycling player, is playing on a cycling tour. The next two routes are 4 centimetres apart on a map of the tour. How far apart are the next two routes in real life if the map uses a scale of 3 centimetres = 2 kilometres?
___ kilometres
solution:
Write a ratio that represents the scale of the map in centimetres to kilometres:
$\frac{3}{2}$

Write a ratio that relates the centimetres between the next two routes on the map to the kilometres between the next two routes in real life:
$\frac{4}{d}$

Use those ratios to set up a proportion and solve.
$\frac{3}{2}=\frac{4}{d}$

Multiply both sides by $d$.
$\frac{3}{2}d = \frac{4}{d}d$

Simplify.
$3d / 2 = 4$
$d = 4 \times 2 / 3$
$d = 2$
The next two routes are 2 kilometres apart in real life.

question_text:
tennis player Serena, a professional tennis player, is playing on a tennis tour. The next two courts are 8 centimetres apart on a map of the tour. How far apart are the next two courts in real life if the map uses a scale of 5 centimetres = 2 kilometres?
___ kilometres
solution:
Write a ratio that represents the scale of the map in centimetres to kilometres:
$\frac{5}{2}$

Write a ratio that relates the centimetres between the next two courts on the map to the kilometres between the next two courts in real life:
$\frac{8}{d}$

Use those ratios to set up a proportion and solve.
$\frac{5}{2}=\frac{8}{d}$

Multiply both sides by $d$.
$\frac{5}{2}d = \frac{8}{d}d$

Simplify.
$5d / 2 = 8$
$d = 8 \times 2 / 5$
$d = 3$
The next two courts are 3 kilometres apart in real life.

question_text:

solution:

Simplify the fraction.
$\frac{160 \text{mm} \div 40}{200 \text{m} \div 40} = \frac{4 \text{mm}}{5 \text{m}}$
The scale of the drawing is 4 millimetres : 5 metres.

question_text:

Multiply both sides by $d$.
$\frac{5}{1}d = \frac{6}{d}d$

$5d / 1 = 6$
$d = 6 \times 1 / 5$
$d = 1$
The next two routes are 1 kilometres apart in real life.

The scale of the drawing is 3 millimetres : 5 metres.

question_text:
musician Jazz measured a concert hall and made a scale drawing. The scale of the drawing was 4 centimetre : 2 metres. The stage is 20 centimetres in the drawing. How wide is the actual stage?
___ metres
solution:
Write the scale of the drawing as a fraction:
$\frac{4\text{cm}}{2\text{m}}$

Write an equivalent fraction with 20 centimetres as the numerator:
$\frac{4 \text{cm} \times 5}{2 \text{m} \times 5} = \frac{20 \text{cm}}{40 \text{m}}$
The actual stage is 40 metres wide.

question_text:
swimmer Michael, a professional swimming player, is playing on a swimming tour. The next two pools are 3 centimetres apart on a map of the tour. How far apart are the next two pools in real life if the map uses a scale of 5 centimetres = 2 kilometres?
___ kilometres
solution:
Write a ratio that represents the scale of the map in centimetres to kilometres:
$\frac{5}{2}$

Write a ratio that relates the centimetres between the next two pools on the map to the kilometres between the next two pools in real life:
$\frac{3}{d}$

Use those ratios to set up a proportion and solve.
$\frac{5}{2}=\frac{3}{d}$

Multiply both sides by $d$.
$\frac{5}{2}d = \frac{3}{d}d$

Simplify.
$5d / 2 = 3$
$d = 3 \times 2 / 5$
$d = 1$
The next two pools are 1 kilometres apart in real life.

question_text:
Lucia drew a scale drawing of Hogwarts castle. In real life, the Quidditch pitch is 75 metres long. It is 150 millimetres long in the drawing. What scale did Lucia use?
2 millimetres : ___ metres
solution:
Write the ratio of the width of the Quidditch pitch in the drawing to the width of the actual Quidditch pitch. Write the ratio in fraction form.
$\frac{150 \text{mm}}{75 \text{m}}$

Simplify the fraction.
$\frac{150 \text{mm} \div 75}{75 \text{m} \div 75} = \frac{2 \text{mm}}{1 \text{m}}$
The scale of the drawing is 2 millimetres : 1 metres.

question_text:
Lucia drew a scale drawing of Final Fantasy airship. In real life, the deck is 150 metres wide. It is 90 millimetres wide in the drawing. What scale did Lucia use?
3 millimetres : ___ metres
solution:
Write the ratio of the width of the deck in the drawing to the width of the actual deck. Write the ratio in fraction form.
$\frac{90 \text{mm}}{150 \text{m}}$

Simplify the fraction.
$\frac{90 \text{mm} \div 30}{150 \text{m} \div 30} = \frac{3 \text{mm}}{5 \text{m}}$
The scale of the drawing is 3 millimetres : 5 metres.

question_text:
cyclist Lance, a professional cycling player, is playing on a cycling tour. The next two routes are 5 centimetres apart on a map of the tour. How far apart are the next two routes in real life if the map uses a scale of 5 centimetres = 1 kilometre?
___ kilometres
solution:
Write a ratio that represents the scale of the map in centimetres to kilometres:
$\frac{5}{1}$

Write a ratio that relates the centimetres between the next two routes on the map to the kilometres between the next two routes in real life:
$\frac{5}{d}$

Use those ratios to set up a proportion and solve.
$\frac{5}{1}=\frac{5}{d}$

Multiply both sides by $d$.
$\frac{5}{1}d = \frac{5}{d}d$

Simplify.
$5d / 1 = 5$
$d = 5 \times 1 / 5$
$d = 1$
The next two routes are 1 kilometres apart in real life.

question_text:
swimmer Michael, a professional swimming player, is playing on a swimming tour. The next two pools are 4 centimetres apart on a map of the tour. How far apart are the next two pools in real life if the map uses a scale of 5 centimetres = 3 kilometres?
___ kilometres
solution:
Write a ratio that represents the scale of the map in centimetres to kilometres:
$\frac{5}{3}$

Write a ratio that relates the centimetres between the next two pools on the map to the kilometres between the next two pools in real life:
$\frac{4}{d}$

Use those ratios to set up a proportion and solve.
$\frac{5}{3}=\frac{4}{d}$

Multiply both sides by $d$.
$\frac{5}{3}d = \frac{4}{d}d$

Simplify.
$5d / 3 = 4$
$d = 4 \times 3 / 5$
$d = 2$
The next two pools are 2 kilometres apart in real life.
